title: Signs Your Dog May Have Parvo (with Pictures)

steps.title: Monitor your dog for lethargy or a lack of appetite.
steps.content: Monitor your dog for lethargy or a lack of appetite. The first sign of a parvo infection is typically lethargy. Your dog may become less active than normal or even seem depressed, eventually retreating to a corner and staying put. [2] X Expert Source Ray Spragley, DVM Veterinarian Expert Interview. 19 February 2021. You might also notice that they don't have much of an appetite and seem weak. [3] X Research source Parvo usually progresses quickly. Lethargy is often quickly followed by vomiting and diarrhea.

steps.title: Watch for signs of a fever.
steps.content: Watch for signs of a fever. Dogs infected with parvo usually develop a high fever. [4] X Research source Signs of fever might include warm ears or a warm nose and red eyes. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Kennel Club The American Kennel Club (AKC) is a purebred dog pedigree registry in the United States. The AKC advocates for the responsible ownership of dogs and promotes purebred dog events, such as the Westminster Dog Show. Go to source Use a rectal thermometer or an ear thermometer to take your dog's temperature . If it's higher than 101–102.5 °F (38.3–39.2 °C), they have a fever. [6] X Research source Any change in temperature can be a sign of parvo. Some dogs might have a lower-than-normal body temperature, instead. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Pay attention to vomiting.
steps.content: Pay attention to vomiting. Parvo attacks the rapidly dividing cells that line the stomach and intestines. This typically causes your dog's stomach to become irritated and ulcerated, which can lead to severe vomiting. [8] X Research source [9] X Expert Source Ray Spragley, DVM Veterinarian Expert Interview. 19 February 2021. Your dog might have trouble holding down food and water, which can quickly lead to severe dehydration and malnourishment. If not treated quickly, this can lead to shock or even death.

steps.title: Watch for diarrhea and bloody stool.
steps.content: Watch for diarrhea and bloody stool. Dogs infected with parvo typically have upset stomachs and diarrhea. The diarrhea is often severe and has an unpleasant and distinctly sickly-sweet odor. [10] X Research source The stool also frequently contains blood. [11] X Expert Source Ray Spragley, DVM Veterinarian Expert Interview. 19 February 2021. If you see this, take your dog to the vet right away. [12] X Research source Parvo is usually transmitted through contact with an infected dog’s feces. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Check for signs of anemia.
steps.content: Check for signs of anemia. Parvo causes gastrointestinal bleeding, which can lead to anemia. [14] X Research source To see if your dog might be anemic, press down on their gums. A healthy dog’s gums will quickly return to their normal color after about 2 seconds. If it takes longer, your dog may be anemic. [15] X Research source Anemia may also lead to a noticeable paleness of your dog’s gums.

steps.title: Be especially mindful of parvo if you have a puppy.
steps.content: Be especially mindful of parvo if you have a puppy. Although parvo can affect older dogs, puppies between 6 and 20 weeks of age are most vulnerable. Parvo is especially serious in puppies because their immune system hasn't fully developed yet. In addition, vaccination may not be fully effective until your puppy is between 14 and 16 weeks old because antibodies in their mother's milk can interfere with the vaccine. [16] X Research source It can be hard to spot the early signs of parvo in a puppy, which unfortunately means the mortality rate can be high for younger dogs. Pay close attention to any changes in their behavior and take them to the vet if you think anything's amiss. [17] X Expert Source Ray Spragley, DVM Veterinarian Expert Interview. 19 February 2021.

steps.title: Take your dog to a veterinarian immediately.
steps.content: Take your dog to a veterinarian immediately. Unfortunately, parvo is fast-acting—it can be fatal in just 48 to 72 hours after the first symptoms appear. Getting your dog to the vet quickly improves their chances of recovery. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Ask your vet to do an ELISA test.
steps.content: Ask your vet to do an ELISA test. To diagnose parvo, your veterinarian may perform the Enzyme-Linked ImmunoSorbent Assay (ELISA) test. This test checks your dog’s stool for evidence of parvo. It can be done in your veterinarian’s office, and the results typically come back in about 15 minutes. [19] X Research source The ELISA test gives rapid results but can result in false positives. Your vet may recommend further testing, like taking a white blood cell count or sending a sample to a lab. On the other hand, more testing to confirm parvo may not be necessary. Parvo causes severe illness which is managed with supportive care rather than a cure. So, it is not always necessary to run diagnostic tests.

steps.title: Get a white blood count for confirmation.
steps.content: Get a white blood count for confirmation. Since ELISA tests sometimes come back with false positives, your vet may also check your dog's white blood cell count. Parvo attacks a dog's bone marrow, so a low white blood cell count is usually a good indicator that your dog has parvo—especially in combination with a positive ELISA test. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Wait for lab results if your vet does a PCR test.
steps.content: Wait for lab results if your vet does a PCR test. In a PCR test, your vet sends a fecal sample from your dog to a lab for testing. The results of this can confirm whether your dog has parvo. [21] X Research source This takes longer than an ELISA test, but the results are typically more accurate.

steps.title: Follow your veterinarian’s suggestions for treatment.
steps.content: Follow your veterinarian’s suggestions for treatment . There is currently no cure for the parvovirus. However, your veterinarian can recommend supportive therapies and practical measures that help increase your dog’s odds of recovery. These might include: [22] X Research source Hospitalization Intravenous fluids Blood transfusion Anti-vomiting medication Anti-diarrheals Antibiotics
